raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "Blunting of costophrenic angle", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "The patient presents with dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased tactile fremitus over the left lung base - this classic triad indicates fluid accumulation in the pleural space (pleural effusion). Key clinical features supporting this include: 1) Recent travel to Southeast Asia with fever/cough suggesting possible infection, 2) Significant weight loss (4 kg over 3 months) raising concern for malignancy or tuberculosis, 3) Long smoking history (41 pack-years) increasing lung cancer risk. Pleural effusion characteristically causes blunting of the costophrenic angle on chest x-ray. The other options don't fit: elevation of diaphragm suggests volume loss/atelectasis, ground glass appearance indicates interstitial disease, and widened intercostal spaces suggest hyperinflation/COPD."}
